newsitem.title: SOUTH KOREA: Seoul listed firms' financial cost burden rises.
newsitem.headline: Seoul listed firms' financial cost burden rises.

text.p: South Korean listed firms saw their financial cost burden grow in calendar 1996 despite a drop in interest rates, the Korea Listed Companies' Association said on Wednesday.
An association statement said the 612 non-financial listed firms paid an average of 30.22 billion won in interest or other financial costs in 1996, up 16.6 percent from 1995.
The growth rate compared with a 16.9 percent rise to an average of 25.92 billion won paid in 1995 from 22.17 billion won in 1994, the statement said.
It said their borrowings, including loans and funds raised through corporate bonds, increased by 21.6 percent to an average of 300.9 billion won in 1996 from 247.4 billion in 1995.
Consequently, their debt-to-turnover ratio rose to 47.28 percent in 1996 from 45.28 percent in 1995.
The ratio compared with 26.8 percent for the United States, 39.6 percent for Japanese and 24.4 percent for companies in Taiwan, said the statement, quoting central Bank of Korea data.
In 1996, the companies borrowed at an average interest rate of 11.23 percent, compared with 11.56 percent in 1995 and 11.41 percent in 1994, the association said.
